result.execSummary:
The defendant Jesse D Reed was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of Narcotic Drugs [Modifiers: Repeater], a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(am).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Defendant is NOT eligible for Challenge Incarceration Program and IS Eligible for Substance Abuse Program. Sentence credit of 104 days were granted.

AS OF 11/12/2018: Court grants that the Defendant IS ELIGIBLE for Challenge Incarceration Program.

superMiscConds.notes: Costs to be paid as a condition of Extended Supervision. DNA Surcharge and sample are waived.

No use or possession of alcohol or illegal drugs/drug paraphernalia. Comply with random urine screens.  Maintain absolute sobriety. No use or possession of prescription drugs without a valid prescription. 
Follow through with After Care. Attend a minimum of 2 Self Help meetings per week.

Maintain full time employment and/or school combination within 6 months of release. DNA Sample is waived. 
  If Probation/Extended Supervision is revoked and/or a prison term ordered, outstanding financial obligations shall be collected pursuant to statutory provisions, including deductions from inmate prison monies.  If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collections may include income assignment.

supervisions.notes: AMENDED ON 12/11/2015:  COURT ORDERS 2 YEARS OF EXTENDED SUPERVISION

Defendant Jesse D Reed in court, in custody, with attorney Joseph Smith.    District Attorney's Office Law Intern appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant enters a guilty plea to Count 1.  Court finds defendant guilty.  Count 2 dismissed and read in.  Case 15CM1020 dismissed and read in to this matter.  Recommendations by the State.  Arguments by the Defense.  Statement by defendant.

Court orders the following: 
- Total sentence: 6 years (Initial Confinement: 3 years, Extended Supervision: 3 years) CONCURRENT with any current sentence. Credit for 104 days.
- Defendant IS NOT eligible for Challenge Incarceration
- Defendant IS eligible for Substance Abuse Program
- Court costs of $268.00 to be paid as a Condition of Extended Supervision.
- DNA Surcharge waived
- DNA Sample waived
- Conditions of Extended Supervision:  Maintain absolute sobriety/Random UAs.  No use or possession of alcohol/drug paraphernalia/drugs without a valid prescription.  Follow through with aftercare.  Attend a minimum of 2 self help meetings per week.  Maintain full-time employment and/or school within 6 months of release.
